Remember, it's important to listen to your body and stay in tune with your hunger and fullness cues to ensure you are nourishing both yourself and your growing baby adequately.

Key nutrients to highlight when teaching about plant-based nutrition to students include protein, iron, calcium, vitamin C, and dietary fiber. 

Protein is essential for growth and repair of tissues, and plant-based sources include legumes, nuts, seeds, and whole grains. Iron is important for oxygen transport in the body, and plant-based sources include beans, lentils, tofu, and fortified cereals. Calcium is crucial for bone health, and plant-based sources include leafy greens, almonds, and fortified plant milks. Vitamin C is important for immune function and iron absorption, and plant-based sources include citrus fruits, strawberries, and bell peppers. Lastly, dietary fiber is important for digestion and reducing the risk of chronic diseases, and plant-based sources include fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and legumes.

Carrots are a rich source of vitamin A, dietary fiber, and minerals such as potassium and calcium. Including carrots in a plant-based diet can provide a range of nutrients essential for overall health.

When teaching about plant-based nutrition, it is important to emphasize a variety of plant-based foods to ensure adequate intake of essential nutrients. Encouraging students to incorporate a diverse range of fruits, vegetables, whole grains, legumes, nuts, and seeds into their diet will help them meet their nutrient needs in a plant-based diet.

To improve skin health through diet, focus on incorporating plant-based foods rich in antioxidants, essential fatty acids, and vitamins that promote skin health. Some beneficial plant-based foods for healthy skin include:

1. Leafy greens like spinach, kale, and Swiss chard are rich in vitamins A, C, and E, which are essential for skin health.

2. Nuts and seeds such as walnuts, chia seeds, and flaxseeds are high in omega-3 fatty acids, which help maintain skin moisture and elasticity.

3. Fruits like berries, oranges, and grapefruits are packed with antioxidants that protect the skin from damage caused by free radicals.

4. Legumes like chickpeas, lentils, and black beans are excellent sources of protein, which is essential for collagen production for healthy skin.

5. Whole grains like quinoa, brown rice, and oats provide essential nutrients like selenium and zinc that promote skin health.

Incorporating these plant-based foods into your diet can help improve skin health and appearance. The antioxidants and nutrients found in these foods can help reduce inflammation, promote collagen production, and protect the skin from oxidative stress. Remember to also stay hydrated and limit processed foods and added sugars for overall skin health.

context: Probiotics are beneficial commensal microbes in human. Microbiota is a large community of microorganisms that grows in the stomach, small and large intestines. The majority of these microorganisms which are beneficial to human body are members of probiotics. The definition of probiotics defined by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations/World Health Organization (FAO/WHO) with minor modified by the International Scientific Association for Probiotics and Prebiotics (ISAPP) is “live microorganisms that when administered in adequate amounts confer a health benefit on the host” (Salminen et al., Microencapsulation is an effective technology to help protect probiotics from stress conditions (Ammara et al., Corn which is abundant in Northern Thailand is a vegetable enriched with nutrients especially soluble corn fiber (SCF).
